subject: Adding detailed alt text to images for accessibility

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages

Patch Set 3:

Michael, thanks for doing this, I am 100% in support of this effort.

It occurs to me that that's a heck of a lot of text in an ALT, and a screen reader is going to have a difficult time navigating it since there's no markup to give clues.  I wonder whether it would be better to put the state transitions in an accompanying table in the "regular" part of the document, and have the ALT statement be something like, "This image presents a state transition diagram.  The information in the diagram is alternatively presented in a state-transition table following the illustration."

I think this would be more useful to visually impaired readers since most screen readers provide pretty good support for navigating tables.  That assumes, of course, that the row and column headers are marked up properly, and I really don't know how good the Sphinx support is for that.

The table would probably be useful for non-visually impaired users, too.  The downside is that now we'd have two different representations to maintain.  So maybe the thing to do here is kill the diagram and replace it with a table, on the theory that the table is accessible to a wider audience.

What do you think?

Patch Set 3:

Brian,
I appreciate your attention to this.  When it comes to accessibility in the physical world, my philosophy is that if you do it right, a space is not only more accessible for someone in a wheelchair, but is also more friendly and usable to fully able-bodied folks as well.  I'm having a hard time seeing how to make that philosophy work here.  I completely agree that it's a ton of alt text, and I don't like that.  I spent some time looking for some sort of a way to add markup of some sort to the alt text, but I came up empty there.  I think the graphics are really useful, and I would hate to replace them with tables that don't visually convey the information as well to sighted individuals.

At least on the statuses page, I think I can incorporate descriptions of the state transitions into the existing text.  In doing so, the alt text can go back to being a simple phrase.  It may also be possible to do that (at least partially) with the domain implementation.  However I don't see a great way of doing that with the database_architecture page or with the architecture page.  

I found an interesting article that discussed hiding text and markup that would be only "visible" to screen readers, but I don't see how I can implement this easily with Sphinx.  There may be ways of updating the Sphinx rules to allow "screen-reader-only" content, although I think that's a significantly bigger effort (although probably quite worthy for Openstack as a whole), but not one I can personally take on at this point.  
http://webaim.org/techniques/css/invisiblecontent/ 

Given that, my thinking at this point for this patch is that it may be best to pull out the alt text in the statuses page (and sprinkle the content into the rest of the page), and leave the admittedly verbose alt text in the other three pages for now.  

What are your thoughts?

Patch Set 3:

recheck

Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)

Michael, a few suggestions inline.

Again, thanks for doing this, and thanks for looking into the Sphinx accessibility support.  My feeling is that there's no sense letting the perfect be the enemy of the good.  Let's get your current changes into the docs, which will improve them a lot, and we can follow up on what can be done to improve Sphinx later.

Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)
Uploaded patch set 5.

Patch Set 5:

Ian-- sorry I missed answering your comment (accidentally submitted the new build before replying)  If I personally were listening to a screen reader go through this, I would be totally lost.  But, I'm trying to put myself in the shoes of a developer who uses a screen reader.  This reads very much like code, and hence should be somewhat familiar.  Also from the various guidelines I've found on the web, the recommendation seems to be to avoid adding unnecessary verbiage.  Someone skilled at using a screen reader can get up to around 300 words per minute.  That's fast, but any unnecessary words still slow the process down.  Ideally, I'd want to put this into some sort of a 2-level HTML list, as the screen reader would make jumping through the list very easy.  Unfortunately, it's not possible to put any markup in the alt text.
